In December 2024, after the sixth dose of chemotherapy, Adam wrote that he and his oncologist were going to meet another doctor. There were no details — only that the meeting should clarify several questions. Later he explained: the other doctor had reviewed the tests and discussed them at length with the oncologist, while Adam himself hardly participated — he waited outside the door. The minutes stretched endlessly.

In the end there remained a sense of uncertainty and anxiety. The atmosphere was heavy: wariness, incomprehension, no clear forecasts.

After the meeting he noticed a change in the oncologist: he became more attentive and more worried — as if reassessing the situation from scratch and preparing for hard decisions.

The time for the next cycle came. Adam immediately saw: the solution in the IV looked different — which meant a new regimen. This chemo proved noticeably heavier than the previous one: the side effects were sharper and harsher.

Then the oncologist told Roxana something important: in two weeks the leukocytes had risen to an abnormal level. That was an alarming signal — the Hodgkin lymphoma had developed resistance; the tumor had stopped responding to the previous therapy.

Together with a consulting specialist, the oncologist analyzed the situation in detail and decided to change the protocol. With the clinic they agreed to replace the regimen — this came as a relief: there was a chance to turn things around.

The new chemo was more complex and tougher, but already after the first dose the leukocytes dropped noticeably — a sign of effectiveness. The oncologist said, restrainedly: now there is a real, if cautious, hope.

Additionally he proposed a course of radiotherapy directed at the most affected areas. The course was scheduled and carried out without delays.

chapters.title: 44. “DON’T TELL ADAM”
chapters.html:
Around the same time news came from Roxana—about Susanna. She wrote that the course of chemotherapy was completed, but unbearable abdominal pain had returned. The cause was a large tumor in the intestine. The situation was aggravated by the fact that, under her insurance, the waitlist for surgery stretched to almost a year. Everyone understood: Susanna could not hold out that long.

It became a hard knot: the sudden tumor knocked everyone off balance.

Adam didn’t know about it—we deliberately kept him in the dark so as not to shatter his already fragile emotional state.

Together with Roxana we decided: remove it immediately, at a private clinic. A friend of mine helped—quickly and confidently, without unnecessary questions or a shadow of distrust. Personal funds were already gone, but thanks to this support we managed to plug the gap at exactly the right moment.

The operation was promptly organized at a specialist clinic.

Later it turned out: the tumor was malignant and kept growing even against chemotherapy. After removal a new course was prescribed—12 procedures. Sadly, the previous regimen had almost no effect and was extremely hard on her.

Susanna herself changed beyond recognition. She believed she would not survive. Yet she bravely accepted chemo—without hysterics, as if silently resigning herself to a coming end, only prolonged and painful. I did not agree with that. I still believed and was ready to do everything possible to pull Susanna through, no matter how hard it was. She is part of our family, our team, and I was ready to do anything to keep her and one day give her a chance to forget this and live a normal, good life.

chapters.title: 45. BETWEEN DEBT AND HOPE
chapters.html:
At the end of 2024 I made a hard personal decision and parted with my apartment. It was an inevitable step.

The next year, 2025, began just as tense as the previous ones, even though I desperately wanted to break free from the chain of troubles stretching practically since 2019—almost six years. The ordeals became especially brutal from 2021, when Adam’s life began to collapse at a monstrous speed: severe illness, loss of access to funds, the feeling of complete defenselessness before the system. But the most irreplaceable pain remained the loss of the few people who truly mattered to him.

Adam continued to receive chemotherapy. It was heavy—but it worked.

In the spring the doctor expressed cautious optimism and set a goal: full remission with a favorable response.

For me it was a breakthrough, almost light at the end of the tunnel. Everything seemed real. I immediately began to plan our meeting. We discussed the autumn—tentatively October—and imagined how we could see each other somewhere in Spain or Italy. Given Adam’s legal status and case restrictions, he would have to petition the court for permission to leave the United States. Theoretically, permission could be granted only for a short period—and that suited us. Because it was not only about the meeting, but about the symbol: the possibility of coming together again not in fear and exhaustion, but in a new space—without illness. In a life that, perhaps, was only beginning.

chapters.title: 46. THE GUARANTOR
chapters.html:
Along with the rays of hope, a new shadow fell. One day Roxana sent a short, almost stunning message: Susanna is gone.

She died.

From the side effects of chemotherapy. She couldn’t withstand them.

It was a terrible blow—for Roxana and for me. I thought about it every day. For weeks.

It became even harder when it turned out that the loan taken out in Susanna’s name, under the contract, had to be paid by the guarantor. The guarantor turned out to be Roxana. The amount was huge; the banks mercilessly froze all her accounts. Even her salary stopped coming in. She wrote to me in a state of real apathy.

I could not leave her in that position. I contacted a friend who had already helped before and—with gratitude and a slight ache at having to ask again—asked for help once more. He agreed without hesitation.

And now—despite losses, despite pain—we were still approaching the finish. A finish in which Adam would remain alive.

chapters.title: 47. STARTING FROM SCRATCH
chapters.html:
After Susanna’s death, Roxana finally decided to leave the country. She wrote that this decision had been ripening for a long time.

Lara also made a fateful choice—to move to a home for the elderly where, as she put it, there would at last be peace.

Roxana was going to start from scratch in another country—democratic, respectful of human dignity. I’m deliberately not naming it to preserve confidentiality, but it truly is a worthy place. Roxana already had a concrete plan: she had contacted a clinic that agreed to take her. A few formalities remained to close, and she expected to manage them in a reasonable time frame.

She leaned on the oncologist’s words, who expressed cautious optimism: with a favorable response, a full remission of Hodgkin’s lymphoma was possible. These words became the starting point. For the first time in a long while, Roxana allowed herself to believe she could breathe freely. She decided to leave behind the pain accumulated over years: death, fear, sleepless nights, breakdowns, despair. Her native country had ceased to be a home—becoming a battlefield where everything dragged on for far too long.

The dogs—Adam’s two and another one Roxana had picked up as a puppy in the street—remained part of this big family: Adam, Roxana, Susanna, and Lara. They were temporarily entrusted to a young woman who agreed to shelter them until the end of 2025.

I supported Roxana’s decision without hesitation. We both understood: a different chapter was beginning—where she could live for herself, without the constant presence of pain, fear, and responsibility. We were ready to change the format of our communication. To free her. Perhaps even completely.

chapters.title: 48. FINISH WITH HURDLES
chapters.html:
In June 2025 Adam was due for the last—and the toughest—dose of chemotherapy. The final step on a long, grueling road. We believed this would put a period at the end. But, as before, nothing went according to plan.

The organization that had been providing housing suddenly withdrew further support. He could no longer stay where he was.

At the same time, logistical obstacles arose that put the timely completion of the final course in doubt.

As a result Adam ended up in a homeless shelter. They gave him a cot, as far from people as possible—to lower the risk of infections.

I kept driving the process, knowing how crucial the last dose was. If a relapse occurred, I would blame myself for life for stopping at the very finish line.

And then chance helped.

At her new workplace, Roxana told a colleague about Adam’s situation. The colleague offered to take him in temporarily. Roxana took on coordination from a distance.

This happened literally a day before the flight to New York: the tickets had already been bought. But after that conversation everything changed—the flight was canceled, and a family of three came to pick him up right from the shelter. He was there in isolation and in a bad state, but the staff were understanding.

The host family made a good impression, though Adam felt awkward and feared being a burden.

He moved in with these kind people and began to recover, getting ready for the final chemotherapy. He behaved as quietly as possible, most of the time pretending to sleep—just so as not to bother anyone. Meanwhile, Roxana organized everything: dates, medications, bookings. Once again she proved a brilliant coordinator, managing the crisis remotely with striking precision.

chapters.title: 49. THE LETTER
chapters.html:
As soon as everything was ready—the place, the housing, the medications—the news came: the family he was living with ran into a sudden housing crisis and had to move out urgently. Adam had to look for a new place again.

I looked for a solution immediately. I considered volunteer platforms for temporary hosting—there were no responses, and the format seemed unsuitable given his condition.

In the end Adam made a decision: to return to New York right after the final dose. As soon as chemotherapy ended, he left the hospital on his own, reached the airport, and flew out. The day was hard, but he made it—strong and determined, despite limited mobility. I was sincerely encouraged: he finished a grueling course and, in the end, walked home on his own feet.

Side effects began at home, in the familiar environment. Days and nights were difficult, but he followed the path to the end—at the cost of immense effort.

The oncologist spoke of the prospect of a full cure—and we allowed ourselves to believe in the good: lightness and hope returned.

I even bought tickets to Italy for early October—we started planning a meeting. It seemed the worst was behind us. Anxiety and uncertainty remained: the therapy had just ended. But we held on to hope.

The calm lasted briefly. Only a couple of weeks—until the end of June.

chapters.title: 50. I STILL SEE A CHANCE
chapters.html:
At the end of June, Roxana wrote: Adam’s blood was drawn for monitoring. The results were worrying—the tests showed an abnormal rise in the counts.

A bolt from the blue. Not long before, the oncologist had spoken of stabilization, even remission.

It was a blow, but I didn’t let myself break. I immediately started parsing it: what does this mean, what options do we have. I asked Roxana to contact the doctor, gathered data, reviewed the medical history. A hypothesis emerged: the leukemia might be back—the one previously suppressed by CAR‑T.

At first no blast cells were found—only marked leukocytosis. One of the lab techs suggested a compensatory reaction after treatment, a temporary surge. I hoped so and considered switching to tyrosine‑kinase inhibitors.

But five days later the repeat test showed otherwise: white blood cells—67,000; leukemic cells of lymphoid type were detected in the blood, and a genetic marker identified. The picture suggested chronic lymphocytic leukemia, but the course was atypically rapid—closer to an acute form. That was frightening.

The oncologist proposed starting with oral chemotherapy, and after stabilization—moving to tyrosine‑kinase inhibitors. A second heavy blow in a short time.

Roxana was crushed. “Niko, we can’t anymore. He can’t. I can’t. And you can’t,” she wrote.

I replied that I still see a chance. And I intend to use it.

chapters.title: 51. REAL — UNREAL
chapters.html:
Adam met the new treatment with sharp rejection. He refused at once: “Enough. I won’t undergo treatment anymore.” He listened to the oncologist’s plan—and rejected it. Resolute. Categorical. Exhausted.

And yet we believed that one more attempt was possible, and we worked to get it started. We discussed the regimen and launched therapy according to the doctor’s plan. Chemotherapy—in liquid form.

On one of the most symbolic days—on my birthday, on Barbara’s birthday, and on the day of the court hearing—the oncologist handed over the course of medications.

On that very day. That’s how everything coincided.

Then I thought again: yes, this is it—our story. Real. Unreal. The Real Unreal Story.

chapters.title: 52. EPILOGUE: THE END ISN’T WRITTEN YET
chapters.html:
We are now on a new branch of our twisted spiral—a story that’s hard to believe, yet, strangely, absolutely real. And I’m still not ready to give up. But I also clearly understand: we can’t handle this alone.

The oncologist proposed a plan: multi‑cycle chemotherapy and, if necessary, repeated radiotherapy—to reduce the risk of relapse. The path is long, and much can go off‑plan. In certain cases, a stem‑cell transplant may be required. A switch to targeted therapy (tyrosine‑kinase inhibitors) is also being considered if we manage to stabilize the process—or, better, eliminate it completely.

The situation has become more complicated: Adam has been diagnosed with leukemia; doctors are specifying the subtypes, and there remain questions about a mixed nature of the process. I also learned that Roxana has been diagnosed with an autoimmune disease. Our anchor, the restraining force, and the heart of the team that remains—now she herself needs protection.

My resources are at their limit. I am physically far away and cannot be next to Adam. And still—I won’t surrender.

I told this story—The Real Unreal Story—so it wouldn’t dissolve. It’s real and it matters. I don’t want all of this to be left without meaning—as if nothing happened, as if the path we walked doesn’t deserve memory, understanding, and a chance at completion.

I told it so it would live—among you. So that, perhaps, someone to whom it resonates could become part of it. Support takes many forms: action, information, participation, even simple attention.

If anything in this story touched you—don’t pass by.

I still believe: this story can end differently. For Adam. For us. Modestly, perhaps, but with a right to life and hope. The ending of The Real Unreal Story has not yet been written.
